threat: If a system was using X.25, a remote attacker could exploit this to crash the system, leading to a denial of service.
A local attacker could exploit this to allocate all available kernel memory, leading to a denial of service.
If a local attacker were able to trigger certain kinds of kernel bugs, they could create a specially crafted process to gain root privileges.
A local attacker could send specially crafted traffic to crash the system, leading to a denial of service.
A local attacker could exploit this crash the system or gain root privileges.
On non-x86 systems, a local attacker could exploit this to read kernel heap memory, leading to a loss of privacy.
If the dvb-ttpci module was loaded, a local attacker could exploit this to crash the system, leading to a denial of service, or possibly gain root privileges.
On systems using InfiniBand, a local attacker could send specially crafted requests to crash the system, leading to a denial of service.
By inserting a specially crafted disk device, a local attacker could exploit this to gain root privileges.
